My Publications

Following are few of my publications...

I have several journal and conferance publications pubblished in reputed journals and conferances. All the publications are in the area of electrical network modelling, simulation & protection.

Development of a hybrid protection scheme for active distribution systems using polarities of current transients

Electrical Power Systems Research
Abstract

The presence of a fault current source in the low voltage distribution level is a major challenge for the protection system designers. This project studied such systems in detail through simulations. Once the key network response trends were identified, novel protection and relaying schemes were proposed and validated through simulations. The contributions include developing an improved protection method for active distribution networks.

Hardware Implementation of Hybrid Protection Scheme for Active Distribution Networks

Journal of Electrical Power & Energy Systems
Abstract

Transient based protection schemes require suitable sensors to detect the high frequency signals. In this work, a new type of sensor is proposed to detect high frequency transients in currents and their initial polarities. Key component of the sensor is an open circuited ferrite core coil. A detailed model of the sensor, including the dynamic hysteresis characteristics of the ferrite coil, is modeled in electromagnetic transient simulation platform. Finally, the model is verified using experimental measurements.

Enhancing the transient stability of distributed generators with adaptive time-overcurrent protection augmented with transient based unit protection

International Conferance on Power System Transients (IPST)
Abstract

This paper investigates the application of a transient based unit protection scheme to implement adaptive characteristics on time over-current relays. Time over-current relays located upstream have longer operating times due to the coordination with the downstream relays. This paper proposes a basic concept of using transient based protection methods to improve the operation times of time over-current relays.

Hardware Implementation of Hybrid Protection Scheme for Active Distribution Networks

IEEE Canada Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC 2018)
Abstract

Implementing a protection scheme that relies on transient signals in the laboratory environment and demonstrating its performance using hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) simulations is an important step needed for real world application of transient based protection methods. In this project, transient-based protection scheme was implemented in a laboratory. Implementation comprised of power network simulated in Real Time Digital Simulation (RTDS) platform, commercial relays (SEL-421) and transient detection sensors. This work further verifies the use of transient based protection strategies for protection applications in active distribution networks.

Detecting fault generated surges in transmission lines of VSC HVDC schemes for traveling wave based fault location

CIGRÃ‰ Canada Conference
Abstract

This paper investigates travelling wave based fault location in voltage source converter (VSC) based HVDC schemes. The selection of appropriate input signals and transducers can potentially increase the accuracy of fault location while reducing the cost and the complexity of the measurement system. Most commercial HVDC line fault locators are designed for traditional line commutated convertor (LCCs) based HVDC schemes where there is a large smoothing reactor between the converter and the DC line. This allows easy detection of fault generated voltage waves by monitoring the current through the surge capacitors connected at the line ends. In VSC HVDC schemes, large smoothing inductors are not necessary and much smaller series inductors may be included for protection purposes. This paper examined the adaptations that may be required to the measurement methods when employed for fault location in VSC based systems. The studies showed that the surge capacitor currents can be used as a signal to detect wave fronts in VSC based HVDC schemes as well, provided that a small series inductor is present between the line and converter terminal.
